Buenos fires, October 14, 1947
Dear Family--
We left New York Tuesday, September 30th, at 7:45 P.M. in a
Pan American DC-4, circled up and out over the home of the desolete
Buns (who had just lost the first gene of the World Series), down
the harbor of New York, and out to sea.
It as a becutiful
moon-
light night and the myriad lights of anhattan - alrays impressive -
were lovelier than ever.
Out over Long Island mith Ber uda as our
first land fell
(don't like that terminology!), where me circle the
station as a check point and if ell's well
carry

Puerto Rico.
we reached Bernuda at around 11:30 P.M., and circled
at 6,000 feet, giving us an unequalled view of ell of
Bermuda in
bright moonlight.
Cities and countrysides - like glamorous als
alrays look better by moonlight.
The freckles and blewishes don't
show up.
Leaving Berruda (760 miles out) without landing, our course
was due south 1,000 miles to Sen Juan.
We stretched out as best
we could and cught five or six hours of sleep before we started
sliding down for a landing at San Juan.
There me landed at four
o'clock in the morning our
time - five a.n.
theirs.
